sub_topic: Identifying the cut vertices and bridges in a graph.
message_1:
Consider the following undirected graph: 

    A --- B --- C
        / \   / \
       D   E F   G

Which vertices are cut vertices (also known as articulation points) and which edges are bridges?
message_2:
A cut vertex (articulation point) is a vertex that, when removed along with its incident edges, increases the number of connected components in the graph. A bridge is an edge that, when removed, increases the number of connected components in the graph.

In the given graph:

Cut vertices (articulation points): B, E
Explanation: 
- If we remove vertex B and its incident edges, the graph will be split into two connected components: {A, D, E} and {C, F, G}.
- If we remove vertex E and its incident edges, the graph will be split into two connected components: {A, B, C, F, G} and {D}.

Bridges: (A, B), (B, C), (B, E), (E, D)
Explanation:
- If we remove edge (A, B), the graph will be split into two connected components: {A, D, E} and {B, C, F, G}.
- If we remove edge (B, C), the graph will be split into two connected components: {A, B, D, E} and {C, F, G}.
- If we remove edge (B, E), the graph will be split into two connected components: {A, B, C, F, G} and {D, E}.
- If we remove edge (E, D), the graph will be split into two connected components: {A, B, C, E, F, G} and {D}.
